I'm about two years late to this party and am not sure if anyone already mentioned this. But, to elaborate on the sprinter large booty vs distance runner flat booty. A sprinting athlete has different mechanics during a sprint than a distance runner on a long run. The variable mechanics causes a different demand for the muscles recruited. Secondly, because of the distance and time spent active during these different movement modalities the energy demand on the muscles will be different, aerobic vs anaerobic. This variance in energy demands causes muscle fibers to adapt differently and become more fast twitch dominant vs slow twitch dominant. Typically, a fast twitch muscle fiber dominant athlete will have more muscular hypertrophy as a byproduct than an athlete that is slow twitch dominant and higher aerobic capacity.

Also, it's worth mentioning that during compounding movements like squats, muscle fiber recruitment can be higher if load/resistance is added and the mechanics/form of the exercise is executed properly. Also, there exist other factors during the executed exercise that can alter muscle fiber recruitment like angle/ROM of movement, variance in speed of execution of exercise, time under tension (holding position), and focus on concentric or eccentric phases.

Muscle fibre type plays a huge role in hypertrophy. Type 2 A and B(x) have greater potential for hypertrophy than Type 1 when looking at physiological cross sectional area. Training Type 2 A and B(x) is predominantly in that upper echelon of strength and power training where we see high force development over short time periods, while type 1 predominantly is endurance training, low force development over long periods of time.
We know this intrinsically when comparing:
a marathon runner, small force over long period of time, less hypertrophy,
vs
a sprinter high force development over a short period of time, more hypertrophy.

The volleyball example would be because the players are using explosive action such as jumping when playing, a jump is high force development over a short period. .

This is a commonly overlooked physics problem that can get folks into trouble (seen it happen, inexperienced rider crashes new motorcycle after ride around the block!). Gyroscopic action takes effect as speed increases, so steering is backward of what you might expect; instead of turning wheel angle, it turns entire vehicle angle, and moments of angular inertia balance between spinning wheels and entire vehicle turning in vertical axis. Genetics are NOT out of our control completely. I studied kinesiology with a focus on epigenetics in grad school. We studies how there are certain genes that have different effects. However through exercise, diet, etc... we can control how those genes are expressed. For example, If i have a gene that makes me predisposed to high blood pressure, if I never push the buttons to trigger the gene then my blood pressure will stay lowered. We found the same for diabetic genes, high cholesterol, etc.. Theres also genes that make you more likely to store more fat, gain more  muscle, but if I never eat whats necessary to gain that fat then the gene wont express, if i never do any resistance training then my muscle wont express that growth.
